Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Constraining the sources, ages and alteration of dissolved and particulate lipids in estuarine and coastal organic matter
Award.AbstractNarration:
Results from carbon-14 studies of biochemical classes of dissolved organic carbon (DOC) and particulate organic carbon (POC) have shown that carbohydrate and protein derive from carbon dioxide that has been recently fixed into organic matter (i.e., modern in age), whereas the lipid fraction is the most highly aged (~103-104 yrs BP) component of both DOC and POC. The older age of the lipid fraction is believed to be due to differences in organic matter sources, residence times, and/or reactivity. However, more studies are needed to understand the age of the lipid fraction and its contribution to the average age of oceanic DOC and POC. For this reason, a scientist from the College of William and Mary Virginia Institute of Marine Science and her collaborator from Ohio State University plan to examine the sources (i.e., terrigenous, marine, natural, anthropogenic), transformations, and fate of lipophilic organic matter across the land-ocean boundary of Delaware Bay and its adjacent coastal waters. To attain their goal, the researcher will carry out a geochemical evaluation of the conservative vs. non-conservative behavior of different organic constituents (i.e., bulk DOC and POC and their lipid components) and their isotopic (delta14C and del13C) signatures as a function of salinity. This will provide information on the overall mean inputs and sinks of each constituent on the scale of the entire estuary. In addition, the photochemical and microbial reactivity of DOC, POC and lipid components will be evaluated in controlled incubation experiments on timescales relevant to estuarine mixing and residence times.
It is anticipated that this study will provide new insights on how the lipophilic organic matter contributes to the age, reactivity, and cycling of DOC and POC in estuarine and coastal waters.

In terms of the broader impacts, at no cost to the project, the scientist from the College of William and Mary Virginia Institute of Marine Science plans to involve graduate students from the Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro in the research project, thereby building a collaboration between U.S. and Brazilian scientists. One graduate student from the College of William and Mary Virginia Institute of Marine Science and one graduate student from Ohio State University would be supported and trained as part of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching objective of this study was to evaluate the factors contributing to the disproportionately older 14C ages of the lipid-containing components of estuarine organic matter (OM) and differences in dissolved and particulate pools in river, estuarine and coastal waters. Results from this study provide a comprehensive evaluation of the processes contributing to the anomalously old ages of the lipid fraction by detailed analyses of both the 14C age and molecular composition of lipid classes in dissolved and particulate organic matter (DOM and POM, respectively). These results will help river, estuarine and coastal biogeochemists and ecosystem ecologists better understand how lipophilic forms of OM contribute to the overall ages, reactivity and cycling of DOM and POM in river, estuarine and coastal waters. This study will further enhance our understanding of the role lipids may play in contributing to the aging of river, estuarine and seawater OM and as potential nutritional resources to associated river, estuarine and coastal food webs.

The intellectual merit of the proposed project lies in a more detailed understanding of carbon and OM fluxes and cycling at the dynamic land-ocean boundary, which is a critical but as-yet unassessed component of both conceptual and quantitative ocean and terrestrial carbon budgets. In addition, the ongoing enigma of the age of the DOM pool in marine systems was directly addressed by specific evaluation of its highly aged lipid components. A number of important broader impacts have resulted from this study, including the integration of research and education ranging from pre-school-12 to undergraduate and graduate coursework, recruitment of under-represented groups to marine and earth sciences research, the education, training and dissertations of several graduate students, training of undergraduate students, and participation by the project investigators, graduate students and postdoctoral fellow in public outreach programs in coastal and environmental change at both VIMS and The Ohio State  University.

A number of major outcomes and findings resulted from this study, the highlights of which follow. 14C analyses of dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC), POM, and the neutral and polar lipid fractions from POM and ultrafiltered DOM (UDOM) indicate that both the neutral and polar lipid fractions had universally greater 14C ages than the bulk forms of carbon and OM.  The neutral lipid fraction was significantly older than the polar lipid fraction at all sampling times and locations, indicating that 1) neutral lipids are derived from geologically older forms of natural and anthropogenic OM than polar lipids, 2) neutral lipids may survive and age for longer periods of time than polar lipids due to mechanisms such as sorptive protection, or 3) some combination of 1 and 2.  The neutral lipid fractions of both POM and UDOM were most highly aged (~15,000-22,000 yrs B.P.) at the riverine site and decreased seaward to between ~5,000 and 10,000 yrs B.P. at the mouth of Delaware Bay.  In contrast to neutral lipids, polar lipids were significantly younger, ranging from 4,000 to 6,000 yrs. B.P. for both POM and UDOM. In addition, polar lipids showed little variation between sampling sites and times.

Isotope-isotope plots (D14C vs. d13C) of both bulk DOM, POM and DIC and their neutral and polar lipid fractions, along with the isotopic values of potential sources of C and OM to the bulk OM, DIC and lipid pools, suggest 1) neutral lipids in Delaware River and estuary are most likely derived from fossil or near-fossil sources such as petroleum, black carbon and terrestrial sedimentary rock (e.g., kerogens), and 2) polar lipids in this system are most likely derived from intermediate aged (e.g., soils, wastewaters, and/or coastal DOM) sources, OR some combination of fossil, intermediate and modern aged (e.g., terrestrial plants, algae, macrophytes) aged sources.

Isotopic mass balances of the neutral+polar lipid fractions against bulk POM and UDOM yielded two important and contrasting findings. First, for POM, isotopic mass balance revealed that the age of bulk POM could in the majority of cases be accounted for solely by the ages and concentrations of the lipid fractions. This suggests that POM age in general in rivers and estuaries may be to a first approximation be exclusively determined by the relatively large amounts and high degree of aging of these two lipid fractions. Second, for DOM, isotopic mass balance revealed that the ages of bulk DOM – unlike those of POM – could not be accounted for by the ages of its neutral and polar lipid components. While the ages of DOM neutral and polar lipids were similar to those of POM lipids, the 1-2 order of magnitude lower concentrations of neutral and polar lipids in DOM vs. POM lessened their overall contribution to DOM age. Therefore, the age river and estuarine DOM as represented by the Delaware River and estuary must include one or more other aged components in addition to lipids.
